lessonActivities.title: SHOULD â€” Giving Advice and Recommendations
lessonActivities.content:
'Should' is widely used to provide advice, make recommendations, or suggest what is considered sensible or appropriate.

Examples:

  • You should bring a jacket; it might get cold later.
  • Students should read the instructions carefully before starting.
examples: You should bring a jacket; it might get cold later.
Students should read the instructions carefully before starting.
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'should' to suggest what is wise, practical, or considerate.

lessonActivities.title: SHOULD â€” Expressing Expectations and Logical Deduction
lessonActivities.content:
'Should' also indicates what you reasonably expect to happen or what seems logically probable based on information.

Examples:

  • The package should arrive by Friday based on the tracking information.
  • If they left early, they should be home now.
examples: The package should arrive by Friday based on the tracking information.
If they left early, they should be home now.
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'should' for reasonable expectations based on circumstances.

lessonActivities.title: OUGHT TO â€” Advice and What Is Appropriate
lessonActivities.content:
'Ought to' is similar to 'should' but often emphasizes moral responsibility or what is considered appropriate. It can also express probability or natural expectations.

Examples:

  • You ought to keep your promises; it's important for trust.
  • Thirty dollars ought to be sufficient for dinner.
examples: You ought to keep your promises; it's important for trust.
Thirty dollars ought to be sufficient for dinner.
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'ought to' for advice with moral weight or to express what seems deserved or reasonable.

lessonActivities.title: Past Forms: Using 'Should Have' and 'Ought to Have'
lessonActivities.content:
'Should have' and 'ought to have' discuss what would have been wise in previous situations. They express regret or indicate that someone failed to do what was recommended.

Examples:

  • You should have read the instructions before starting.
  • They ought to have left earlier; now they might be late.
examples: You should have read the instructions before starting.
They ought to have left earlier; now they might be late.
lessonActivities.tips: Use 'should have' or 'ought to have' to discuss what would have been better in the past.
